description: From Middle English ambages, from Old French ambages (modern French ambages), from Latin ambāges, from ambi- + agere (“to drive”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) Indirect or roundabout ways of talking; circumlocution.
examples: Thus from her cell Cumæan Sibyl sings / Ambiguous ambages, the cloyster rings / With the shrill sound thereof, in most dark strains.

entries.meaning: (archaic) Indirect or roundabout routes or directions.
examples: Paris put fear into him, a city of monstrous size to which London was but a market town. Its ambages of streets bewildered.
